message.content:
Sure! Here's an example using the matplotlib library:
```python
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load your dataframe into a variable called df
df = pd.read_csv('your_dataframe.csv')

# Select the two columns you want to compare and set them as x and y axes
x_col = 'column1'
y_col = 'column2'

# Plot the data using scatter plot
plt.scatter(df[x_col], df[y_col])

# Set the title, labels, and axis limits
plt.title('Comparison of Columns')
plt.xlabel(x_col)
plt.ylabel(y_col)
plt.xlim([min(df[x_col]), max(df[x_col])])
plt.ylim([min(df[y_col]), max(df[y_col])])

# Show the plot
plt.show()
```
Make sure to replace 'your_dataframe.csv' with the actual file name and path of your dataframe, and update the values of x_col and y_col to match the names of your columns. This code will create a scatter plot where each data point represents a row in your dataframe, with the values of x_col on the x-axis and y_col on the y-axis. You can adjust the appearance of the plot by modifying the parameters passed to plt.scatter(), plt.title(), plt.xlabel(), plt.ylabel(), and plt.xlim(). Let me know if you have any further questions!
